docs.title: Welcome to Universal Arena
docs.text: This site outlines the structure and references for Universal Arena. Add your own content as you grow the guide.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This guide summarizes core systems and links to the detailed reference pages for terms, keywords, and characters.

docs.title: Board
docs.text:
1. Deck Zone: This is where you place your deck. The pile named Draw Pile.
  2. Discard Zone: This is where you place your discarded cards. The pile named Discard Pile.
  3. Combat Zone: This is where you place your card when you play it. The zone divided into 3:
    1. Fast Zone: This is where you play your fast card.
    2. Normal Zone: This is where you play your fast/normal card.
    3. Slow Zone: This is where you play your fast/normal/slow card.

docs.title: How To Play
docs.text:
1. Each player choose their characters. There cannot be the same character with the same Name and Version on one team.
  2. Play divided into 3 phase. Turn Start, Combat, Turn End.
  3. At Turn Start, each player draw until they have 5 cards in hand and 5 energy.
  4. At Combat Start, when the player with initiative play a card to initiate the Combat Round.
  5. At Combat Round, each player play and clashes.
  6. At Combat End, when there are no cards on any zone after any Combat Round.
  7. At Turn End, all player discard all remaining cards and then pass the initiative to the next player.

docs.title: Playing Cards
docs.text:
1. To play any cards, pay the energy cost, select the legal target, then place them on the Combat as stack each according to their speed (normal/slow).
  2. If the said cards have fast speed, the card will instantly be resolved without waiting to be resolved on the stack.
  3. For each card played, you gain ultimate meter equivalent to the energy spent using the card +1.

docs.title: How To Combat
docs.text:
1. You can only play 1 card on one zone per round, except when you playing Special Card. Special Card do not count towards this limit.
    • Fast card can be placed at any zone.
    • Normal card can be placed at Normal/Slow Zone.
    • Slow card can only be placed at Slow Zone.
  2. When you're done, you can declare to end your Round. Your Combat Round is over and then passed to the opponent.
  3. On your opponent's round, your opponent can play any card to counter the card that you've played. That is called Clashing.
  4. After your opponent play a card to counter your card, you can also play any card to counter it.
  5. Clashing will end when the Round passed to the player that have the last card played.
  6. When Clashing end, the Clashing will resolve from the last card played to the very first card played.
  7. Resolve the Clash in Pair against opponent's card. If when paired both card are from the same player or there are no card left to paired, the remaining card will be resolved.
  8. If at any point you or your opponent play on faster zone, that card must be resolved first before continuing to the next zone.
    • Example:
      1. You play a card on Normal Zone.
      2. Your opponent play a card to counter your card and start Clashing.
      3. You play another card on that Clash.
      4. Instead of countering your card, your opponent play another card at Fast Zone.
      5. The Combat now will focus and resolved on the Fast Zone. If you declare not to counter it, then the Card on the Fast Zone will be resolved first before continuing the Clashing on the Normal Zone.
  9. When all the Clash has been resolved and no cards on any zone, the player with initiative can play any card again and start over the Combat Round, or end their turn.

docs.title: How to Clash
docs.text:
1. Attack VS Attack: The card with the most damage dealt won. The card that is lost will omit any damage part and nullified any on hit effect. The other effect will still be resolved and then discarded. The winning card will not be resolved yet, but goes through the stack.
    • If draw, both card will considered loses.
    • If against multihit, use the total damage dealt to compare.
  2. Attack VS Defense: The defense card will activate and give shield. Then the attack will be resolved and considered hit. Both card then discarded.
  3. Defense VS Defense: Both defense card will activate and give shield. Both card then discarded.
  4. Any VS Special: Both card will be activated. Both card then discarded.

docs.title: Characters
docs.text:
1. Copy docs/characters/template.md to docs/characters/<slug>.md.
  2. Prefer character artwork in docs/assets/characters/ and reference it with a relative URL (avoids broken external images).
  3. Add the page to mkdocs.yml under the Characters nav section.
  4. Add a card to docs/characters/index.md:
<a class="character-card" href="<slug>/" data-name="Name" data-version="Version" data-tags="tag1,tag2">
  <div class="character-card__title">Name</div>
  <div class="character-card__meta">Version: Version</div>
  <div class="character-card__tags">Tags: Tag 1, Tag 2</div>
  <p class="character-card__summary">One-line summary.</p>
</a>

docs.title: Card Types
docs.text:
This page lists card types and what they mean in play.

Explanation

Card Types describe what a card is (and usually what rules it follows), such as when it can be played, how it resolves, and what effects or synergies refer to it.

In character pages (example: Rover (Spectro)), card types appear in the card block as a comma-separated list like Physical, Attack, Slash, Debuff.

Use this page as a reference list: add each card type as its own entry, and keep the description short and rules-focused.

docs.text:

docs.title: Examples (from Rover (Spectro))
docs.text:
These are starter examples you can edit/replace as you define your rules.

Attack

Category Action.

A card that deals damage or directly contributes to dealing damage.

Defense

Category Action.

A card focused on protection or mitigation (example: granting Shield).

Debuff

Category Effect.

A card that applies negative effects, status effects, or other hindrances to enemies.

Recovery

Category Effect.

A card that restores resources (example: healing HP).

Physical

Category Damage Type.

Indicates the card’s damage is physical (and can be referenced by rules that care about physical damage).

Magical

Category Damage Type.

Indicates the card’s damage is magical (and can be referenced by rules that care about magical damage).

Slash

Category Attack Tag.

An attack subtype used for rules and synergies that care about “slash” attacks.

Blunt

Category Attack Tag.

An attack subtype used for rules and synergies that care about “blunt” attacks.

docs.title: FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions)
docs.text:
This page collects frequently asked questions about Universal Arena.

How to use this page

Add each FAQ as its own Q/A block. Keep answers short and link to deeper pages when needed.

docs.title: Q: How do I win a match?
docs.text: A: Reduce the opposing team’s HP to 0 (or meet the scenario’s win condition, if you’re playing a special mode).

docs.title: Q: How does Ultimate Meter work?
docs.text: A: You gain Ultimate Meter as you play cards; once you have enough, you can pay the Ultimate Meter cost to use your Ultimate card.

docs.title: Q: Can I bring two of the same character?
docs.text: A: Not if they have the same Name and Version on one team.

docs.title: Status Effects
docs.text:
This page explains what status effects are and how their values work.

Explanation

Status Effects are conditions that can be applied to units on either side of a battle through the use of passives, skills, ultimates, and even other status effects.

A status effect can use up to two values to function, which will be called "modes" here for clarity:

  • Zero-value mode: the value is always fixed at 1 and has no inherent effect on the status effect's strength.
  • Single-value mode: one value is typically called Count, Stack, or Value.
  • Double-value mode: two values (Potency + Count). Generally, Potency determines strength, while Count determines duration.

In single-value or double-value modes, if one or more of the values reach 0, the status effect is removed from the unit. Values are always consumed before they are gained or inflicted.

Status effects also come with a few attributes:

  • Base Value: the initial value on infliction if none is specified.
  • Max Value: the maximum value (default 99).

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
Use the filter to quickly locate a mode, rule, or attribute.

Filter status effects

Burn

Type Negative.

Potency Max 999.

Count Max 99.

Allies Card Played Take Potency damage. Then reduce Count by Energy spent.

Turn End Take Potency damage. Then reduce Count by Halve.

Bleed

Type Negative.

Potency Max 999.

Count Max 99.

Allies Card Played Take Potency damage. Then increase Potency by Energy spent.

Turn End Reduce Count by Halve.

Poison

Type Negative.

Potency Max 999.

Count Max 99.

Allies Card Played Increase Potency by Energy spent.

Turn End Take Potency damage. Then reduce Count by Halve.

Haste

Type Positive.

Max Stack 10.

Turn Start Increase number of cards drawn by Stack.

Turn End Reduce Stack by Halve.

Slow

Type Negative.

Max Stack 10.

Turn Start Reduce number of cards drawn by Stack.

Turn End Reduce Stack by Halve.

Stun

Type Negative.

Max Stack 1.

Turn Start Skip the turn.

Turn End Expires.

Strength

Type Positive.

Potency Max 10.

Count Max 99.

Effect Increase damage dealt by 10% x Potency.

Turn End Reduce Count by Halve.

Weak

Type Negative.

Potency Max 10.

Count Max 99.

Effect Reduce damage dealt by 10% x Potency.

Turn End Reduce Count by Halve.

Vulnerable

Type Negative.

Potency Max 10.

Count Max 99.

Effect Increase damage received by 10% x Potency.

Turn End Reduce Count by Halve.

Zero-value mode

Fixed at 1. The value exists for consistency, not scaling.

Single-value mode

One value (often Count, Stack, or Value) defines the effect and/or duration.

Double-value mode

Two values: Potency (strength) and Count (duration).

Removal at 0

In single- and double-value modes, reaching 0 on any value removes the status effect.

Consumption order

Status effect values are always consumed before they are gained or inflicted.

Base Value and Max Value

Base Value is the default on infliction; Max Value caps growth (default 99).

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
Filter terms

Tip

Add new rows or columns here as rules evolve.

Term Definition Energy The resource used to play cards. By default, you gain energy at the start of your turn until you have 5 energy. Draw The act of taking cards from your Draw Pile and adding them to your hand. By default, you draw at the start of your turn until you have 5 cards. Draw The act of moving a card from your hand to the Discard Pile. Unplayed cards are typically discarded at the end of each turn. Some card effects also cause you to discard cards during your turn. Initiative Who takes the first action each round. Ultimate Meter Resource that powers the strongest abilities. Shield Temporary protection that soaks damage before HP. Self Character that use the Card. Allies All Characters on the same team. Enemies All Characters on the opposite team.
